I'm very surprised you didn't mention 'Come and See'. When I saw 'Beasts of no Nation' I saw it as a modern parallel of the 20th century childhood experience of war. 'Come and See' follows the experience of a Soviet boy behind the lines of the Nazis in the Eastern front. He joins a partisan group, eager to liberate his homeland but by the end is tortured, broken and alienated.

Where as 'Come and See' has two clear sides with good guys and bad guys destroying the lives of those trapped in-between them, 'Beasts of no Nation' shows the confusing, multi sided nature of modern war. In my eyes they are pretty direct parallels of each other and I'd highly recommend both.

My husband who is from Gambia would not even watch this movie until I was scrolling on Netflix one night. It was all kinds of emotions. It was so beautifully done, although hard to watch in some scenes. Although it was not overly gory, you knew exactly what was happening in each scene. Unless I
want to cry and and feel absolutely mortified again I might not watch for a long time however, perhaps for the seemlessness in direction and cinematic genius, I would watch it once more. We bawled like babies but obviously it was worth while and I think everyone should see Beasts of No Nation at least once in their life.

P.S

Very proud of this movie that was shot in my home country Ghana 🇬🇭. Even though it's supposed to be set in  an unnamed African country, it's still VERY Ghanaian, with the local language spoken, the mannerisms of the characters, and also the use of some well known local actors. Very very VERY proud of Abraham Attah who played the hell out of this role (with no former acting experience) and went on to land a role in Spiderman: Homecoming 😁😁. So proud of him and what his future holds. Also, the actor who plays the soldier who was Agu's first kill, is a volunteer in the children's ministry at my church 😁
